bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Wickliffe Rose, October 21, 1921

div1.p: Hanson offers his opinions on the Peruvian government in regards to funding.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Wickliffe Rose, October 21, 1921
div1.opener:
DIRECCION DE LA CAMPAÑA SANITARIA
CONTRA LA FIEBRE AMARILLA
EN LOS
DEPARTAMENTOS DEL NORTE
---
OFICINA CENTRAL
----
Chiclayo, Peru.
October 21, 1921.
Dr. Wicliffe Rose, General Director,
The International Health Board,
61 Broadway New York City,
My Dear Doctor Rose:
div1.p:
I am inclosing herewith copies of letter to the “Salubridad”
giving them a status of my salary up to the middle of this month. My object in
presenting this statement is to try to get a liquidation up to the end of June
at least, as it does not seem to me fair that The International Health Board
should be expected to pay all these back accounts. My procedure in some of these
points is probably a bit arbitrary, but I do not see what else I can do under the
circumstances. In accepting the terms of the memorandum which I presented to the
President the Government recognizes as legal debt 50% of the expenses of the
Campaign, which improves the moral tone - if not the financial contribution.

Together with this you will find the draft on the National Treasury
for Lp 682.5.34, endorsed to the Rockefeller Foundation, and await your further
instructions in regard to this ratter.

You will also find a resume of the checks drawn on the Equitable Trust
Co. Practically all the checks to the banks have been drawn in duplicate, except
the last two to the National City Bank of New York, Lima Branch, and the last one
to the Banco Mercantil Americano del Peru in Chiclayo. In addition there is a
resume of the funds, in Peruvian currency, used in the Department of Lambayeque,
this was made for my personal convenience as a reference, I enclose it since it
may also be of use to the Comptroller.

In regard to Mr. Seeley's salary I have been in error in reporting that
as running from the 4th to the 4th of each month. His last month ended October 16,
and will be paid this month in Peruvian currency from the general campaign funds
and in the future will probably figure in the general statement presented to the
2. Dr. Wicliffe Rose, October 21, 1921.
International Health Board and to the Government.

In regard to his service I have talked the matter over with him and
made an arrangement by which he is to bring his family to the Port of Eten and
continue with the campaign until its finish. I do not feel that he can be spared,
it would be unsafe, not to have some one in whom I can have full confidence for
the balance of the time of the campaign. Everything looks rosy at present, but
the warm weather is coming on, and we do not want to let the breeding increase
until we are ready to bid the country our final farewell. He did not feel that
he could afford the expense of bringing the family and paying the rent in addition
so I proposed that we furnish him quarters for the balance of the campaign, and
that he bring the family which he has agreed to do. This will cost us about ten
pounds per month. We will save half of that on his hotel bill since he will have
maintenance only when away on the outside inspections.
div1.closer:
Respectfully yours, Henry Hanson,
Director of Campaign.
